Due to three new RCT [605-608], comparing the route of biopsy, an updated meta-analysis was performed by the panel [609]. A total of eleven randomised studies including 3,306 patients compared the impact of biopsy route on infectious complications. Infectious complications were significantly higher following transrectal biopsy (64 events among 1,638 men) compared to transperineal biopsy (32 events among 1,668 men), [RR (95% CIs) 1.85 (1. 07 to 3.19)] [605-607, 609, 610]. In addition, a systematic review including 165 studies with 162,577 patients described sepsis rates of 0.1% and 0.9% for transperineal and transrectal biopsies, respectively [611]. Finally, a population-based study from the UK (n=73,630) showed lower re-admission rates for sepsis in patients who had transperineal versus transrectal biopsies (1.0% vs, 1.4%, respectively) [612].

There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that antibiotic prophylaxis may not be required for transperineal biopsy; however, as all recommendations on prostate biopsy are based on level 1a evidence, the Panel has chosen to wait until a number of ongoing RCTs report their study findings before making a recommendation on this.

Local anaesthetic ultrasound-guided transperineal biopsy (LATP) is gaining popularity in this setting; however, there is uncertainty regarding prostate sampling, infection rates, tolerability, side-effects, and cost-effectiveness.

TRANSLATE was a randomised clinical trial that aimed to compare detection of Gleason Grade Group (GGG) 2 or higher prostate cancer, side-effects, tolerability, and patient-reported outcomes, after LATP versus TRUS biopsy.
LATP biopsy was performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation, without antibiotics.
TRUS biopsy was performed using local anaesthetic infiltration, with pre-procedure and post-procedure antibiotics as standard-of-care at each recruitment centre.
None of the TRANSLATE recruitment centres used enhanced prophylaxis or rectal culture-guided prophylaxis, as this is not routinely used in the UK.
Infection requiring admission to hospital within 35 days post-biopsy occurred in 2 (<1%) of 562 participants in the LATP group compared with 9 (2%) of 564 in the TRUS group.

According to the pre-defined primary definition of post-biopsy infection (infection requiring admission to hospital), in the first 7 days post-biopsy this occurred in one (<1%) of 562 individuals allocated to LATP versus seven (1%) of 564 allocated to TRUS biopsy (OR 0.14 [95% CI 0.02-1-15]; table 4).
In the 4-month post-biopsy period there were fewer infectious complications overall with LATP than with TRUS (six [1%] of 562 for LATP versus 13 [2%] of 564 for TRUS, adjusted 0.45 [0.17-1-20]).
Most participants who received LATP underwent biopsy without antibiotics according to protocol (503 [89%] of 567). All participants in the TRUS group received antibiotics (appendix 1 p 17).
Physicians are considering shifting from TRUS to LATP for diagnostic prostate biopsies3,7,11,12,15 to reduce infectious complications.

TRANSLATE demonstrates fewer post-biopsy infection hospitalisations following LATP versus TRUS, with 89% of LATP biopsies not receiving antibiotics (the 11% of LATP cases receiving antibiotics being largely protocol deviations).
Thus, TRANSLATE demonstrates that most LATP biopsies can be safely performed without antibiotics, which is important for antibiotic stewardship.
We recognise that excluding participants at higher risk of infection, necessary for successful randomisation, likely reduced the infection event rate in both groups of this study.

LATP biopsy was performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation, without antibiotics.

TRANSLATE demonstrates fewer post-biopsy infection hospitalisations following LATP versus TRUS, with 89% of LATP biopsies not receiving antibiotics (the 11% of LATP cases receiving antibiotics being largely protocol deviations). The transrectal approach is noted to contravene antibiotic stewardship principles, a central focus of the 2024 European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines on urological infections. These guidelines provide evidence-based recommendations for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention, emphasizing antimicrobial stewardship to minimize antibiotic use and combat the escalating global threat of antimicrobial resistance through specific guidance on antibiotic selection, dosing, and duration, while acknowledging weak evidence for prophylaxis in some procedures like prostatectomy.

Both biopsy approaches demonstrate low overall toxicity, are generally safe for clinical use in the populations studied, and the transperineal (TP) approach does not carry an increasing risk of urinary retention. While there is a clear trend across studies to minimize antibiotic use to reduce antibiotic resistance, recent European Association of Urology guidelines specifically direct urologists towards the TP approach.

The American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines maintain a neutral position on both transrectal and transperineal approaches due to a lack of comparative RCTs on infection rates, also stating that the value of prophylactic antibiotics in TPBx is unknown and its wider implementation requires adequate training and resources. Meanwhile, the European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines describe growing evidence suggesting antibiotic prophylaxis may not be required for TPBx, but the panel awaits ongoing RCT findings, mindful that unnecessary prophylactic antibiotic administration can lead to antibiotic resistance across the medical system.

The exclusive adoption of transperineal (TP) biopsies reduces antibiotic usage by decreasing infectious complications and safely omitting periprocedural antibiotic prophylaxis. This is a crucial point for the urological community's debate on optimal biopsy approaches, given the significant implications of antibiotic overuse and associated antimicrobial resistance (AMR) for individual patients, the general population, and their microbiome.

An updated meta-analysis of eleven RCTs including 2,237 men showed that use of a rectal povidone-iodine preparation before transrectal biopsy, in addition to antimicrobial prophylaxis, resulted in a significantly lower rate of infectious complications [RR (95% CIs) 0.47 (0.36 to 0.61)].

Mechanical cleaning methods with saline are cheap, easy to apply, and have no side effects, protecting against possible infections like other antiseptic solutions with similar results for general complications, fever, acute prostatitis, and sepsis, and serving as an alternative for patients with antiseptic allergies.

Given increasing infection rates and antibiotic resistance, particularly to commonly used quinolones, rectal cleansing with povidone-iodine combined with antibiotic prophylaxis during transrectal biopsy has been shown to reduce infectious complications. Current urology guidelines recommend this approach when local infectious complication rates are high.

Transrectal cleansing with Povidone-iodine is an additional measure to reduce infection during transrectal biopsy. This approach, supported by a meta-analysis of 11 studies (2,237 patients) showing a relative risk of 0.47 (95% CI 0.36-0.61), is a new consensus-based recommendation for 2025.

The EAU strongly recommends the Transperineal (TP) approach due to its reduced incidence of infectious complications, while the AUA, citing limited RCT data, offers unclear guidance but considers both TP and Transrectal (TR) approaches safe and appropriate diagnostic procedures. Although both approaches provide similar diagnostic power, infectious complications appear to favor TP, thus future research must be adequately powered and follow standardized definitions for infectious outcomes.

High-level evidence confirms that the transperineal (TP) biopsy route significantly reduces the risk of infectious complications requiring hospitalisation compared to the transrectal route. Hospitalisation serves as the most sensitive surrogate for serious infections (not meeting sepsis criteria), reflecting increased severity of complications and a higher risk of sepsis; furthermore, antibiotic prophylaxis offers no additional benefit in a TP biopsy, reinforcing antimicrobial stewardship principles.

Clear international guidance on biopsy routes and infection risk, grounded in robust evidence, is needed to support consistent and safe clinical practice across regions. These results may help inform decisions about biopsy technique and infection prevention strategies.

There was a significant association between biopsy approaches and fever, with fever occurring more frequently after TR biopsies, while the TP route showed less frequent postinterventional fever (OR 0.68, 95% CI 0.52-0.89). Furthermore, the TP route significantly reduced the risk of hospitalization for infectious complications by 77% compared to the TR route (OR 0.23, 95% CI 0.10-0.54), with no statistically significant difference in infectious complications for TP biopsies whether antibiotics were used or not, unlike TR biopsies which universally utilized antibiotic prophylaxis.
Use rectal cleansing with povidone-iodine in men prior to transrectal prostate biopsy.

For transrectal prostate biopsy, moderate evidence from numerous low-to-moderate quality studies and four meta-analyses suggests that targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP) guided by pre-procedural rectal swab results, coupled with Povidone-iodine rectal disinfection to minimize bacterial load, is suitable for reducing postoperative infectious complications. While one meta-analysis (Jazayeri et al. 2020) reported a lower but non-significant infection rate with targeted PAP, its authors still concluded its suitability; conversely, two recent RCTs (Jacewicz 2022; Chernyscheva 2021) found no higher rates of infection, fever, or sepsis when PAP was omitted.

Rectal povidone-iodine cleansing before transrectal prostate biopsy, combined with antimicrobial prophylaxis, is strongly recommended due to a meta-analysis of eleven RCTs (2,237 men) showing it significantly lowers infectious complications (RR: 0.47; 95% CI [0.36–0.61]); conversely, the transperineal approach is strongly recommended for prostate biopsy given its low infectious risk and improved antibiotic stewardship.

Rectal cleansing prior to transrectal prostate biopsy appears to be the most effective strategy for reducing infectious complications, including sepsis, potentially outperforming transperineal biopsy and rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis. However, despite current guidelines recommending transperineal biopsy, its effectiveness compared to rectal cleansing and culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis remains unclear, necessitating further randomized controlled trials.

The transperineal approach is recommended for prostate biopsy due to its lower risk of infectious complications and better antibiotic stewardship. While emerging evidence suggests antibiotic prophylaxis may not be required for transperineal biopsy, a panel is awaiting further RCT findings for a formal recommendation, given that all prostate biopsy recommendations require level 1a evidence.

While guidelines now recommend transperineal (TPB) over transrectal (TRB) prostate biopsy, and empirical antibiotics alone are not recommended for TRB, there is insufficient evidence to abandon TRB when combined with rectal cleansing and culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis. These modifications significantly reduce infectious complications, potentially comparable to or even better than TPB, but direct comparisons are scarce, necessitating further RCTs to determine the safest approach.

A systematic review and meta-analysis comparing transrectal (TR) and transperineal (TP) prostate biopsy techniques, which offer similar diagnostic power, found that the TP route significantly reduces the risk of hospitalization due to infectious complications. This evidence reinforces antimicrobial stewardship principles by highlighting the lack of additional benefit from antibiotic prophylaxis in TP biopsies, addressing previous urological guideline inconsistencies and supporting the European Association of Urology's recommendation of TP as the preferred approach for prostate cancer diagnosis.

An updated meta-analysis of ten RCTs (4188 prostate biopsies) found the transperineal (TP) approach to be associated with lower rates of infectious complications, including hospitalisation (77% reduced risk; odds ratio 0.23, 95% CI 0.10-0.54) and fever (odds ratio 0.68, 95% CI 0.52-0.89), compared to the transrectal (TR) route. Notably, all TR biopsies utilized antibiotic prophylaxis, whereas TP biopsies showed no significant difference in infectious complications with or without antibiotics.

Our trial, which focused on patients with low infectious risk (373 finished out of 403 enrolled before early termination on April 8, 2024), implicated that screening with selective media before TRPB may provide additive value to preventing post-biopsy prostatitis. Piperacillin/tazobactam can be recommended when FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli is detected, while further evaluation of selective media screening is needed for patients with underlying conditions negatively impacting immune function.
Piperacillin/tazobactam (TAZ/PIPC) can be recommended or considered when FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli is detected.

Selective media, including 2 kinds of CHROMagar media, utilize dissolved antimicrobials to rapidly and effectively detect targeted strains such as FQ-resistant and ESBL-producing E. coli, thereby improving screening accuracy. These media can be prepared for specific antimicrobials to guide appropriate targeted prophylaxis, providing additive beneficial value for patients undergoing TRPB by addressing worldwide trends in antimicrobial resistance.

In the control group (CG), the positive-culture group administered TAZ/PIPC developed no acute bacterial prostatitis, and the incidence of post-biopsy prostatitis (0/67 cases) was not significantly different from the 3/120 cases observed in the negative-culture group administered LVFX (P = .19).

While transrectal prostate biopsy, even with preoperative rectal screening for multi-drug resistant organisms and targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (t-PAP) reducing broad-spectrum antibiotic use by over 80% (favorable for antibiotic stewardship), still carries inherently higher infection rates (5-7%) and a sepsis risk (0.3-9.4%), the transperineal approach offers a superior alternative. Transperineal biopsy, with comparable tumor detection and a significantly lower infection rate (0% even without prophylaxis versus 1.4% for transrectal with PAP), can often entirely forgo antibiotic prophylaxis, thereby aligning more strongly with antibiotic stewardship principles, provided thorough perineal disinfection and urinary tract infection exclusion are performed.

Antimicrobial prophylaxis is recommended for transrectal prostate biopsy, involving targeted prophylaxis based on rectal or stool culture, augmented prophylaxis with two or more antibiotic classes, or alternative antibiotics such as cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefixime) and aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin, amikacin). However, while fosfomycin trometamol (e.g., 3g before and 3g 24-48h after biopsy) is listed as an alternative, its indication for prostate biopsy has been withdrawn in Germany due to manufacturers' failure to submit necessary pharmacokinetic data, requiring urologists to check local guidance regarding its use.

While direct comparisons are scarce, current findings suggest insufficient evidence to recommend abandoning transrectal prostate biopsy, making it a prudent option for urologists and further trials alongside transperineal biopsy. For transrectal biopsy, pre-procedural rectal cleansing or rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis significantly reduce infectious complications, potentially equalling or surpassing transperineal outcomes, and are recommended over empirical antibiotics alone.

Antibiotic prophylaxis before TRPB is mandatory to avoid infectious complications, but the previous gold standard FQs are no longer accepted in the EU for this indication. In a study, there was no significant difference in infectious complications between single-dose and prolonged FMT prophylaxis for TRPBs, and previous antibiotic treatment showed no negative effect on FMT efficacy; therefore, single-dose FMT is recommended to prevent overuse and negative ecological impact.

During targeted prophylaxis, a non-FQ/nonquinolone alternative antibiotic (e.g., FMT) is still needed; augmented prophylaxis, a second suggestion, might have a potential negative ecological impact and is contrary to antibiotic stewardship principles.

Antibiotic prophylaxis before TRPB is mandatory to avoid infectious complications, but the previous gold standard FQs are no longer accepted in the EU for this indication. The current EAU guidelines recommend an algorithm for prophylaxis, outlining options such as targeted prophylaxis (based on rectal swab results, requiring a nonquinolone alternative, and not always feasible), augmented prophylaxis (with potential negative ecological impact and contrary to antibiotic stewardship), and the use of non-FQ alternative antibiotics like FMT.

A systematic review and meta-analysis of RCTs found that targeted prophylactic antibiotics (TPAs) based on rectal swab culture, when used prior to TRUS-PB for PCa diagnosis, significantly reduce the incidence of febrile UTI (fUTI) by twofold compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics; however, there was insufficient evidence to show a significant difference regarding the risk of sepsis.

The study aimed to assess the efficacy of targeted prophylactic antibiotics (TPAs), based on rectal swabs, in reducing infectious complications after TRUS-PB compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics. This follows a previous meta-analysis [6] which showed that combining prophylactic antibiotics with povidone-iodine rectal preparation before TRUS-PB significantly reduces the incidence of febrile urinary tract infection (fUTI) compared to empiric prophylactic antibiotic monotherapy (RR: 0.47, 95% CI: 0.3-0.75, p = 0.001).

Two RCTs, ProBE-PC (monocentric, 753 patients, 30-day composite infection rate) and PREVENT (multicenter, 658 patients, 7-day post-biopsy infection rates), found no significant difference in composite infection rates between transperineal (TPBx) and transrectal (TRBx) biopsies (2.7% vs. 2.6%, p=0.89 for ProBE-PC; 0% vs. 1.4%, p=0.059 for PREVENT). While TRBx involved targeted antibiotics based on rectal cultures, TPBx typically either prescribed antibiotics without cultures (employing augmented oral therapy or intramuscular ceftriaxone) or omitted prophylaxis in most cases (98.9%), and neither approach induced sepsis in the ProBE-PC trial.

LATP biopsy, performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation, typically did not involve antibiotics for most participants (503 [89%] of 567) according to protocol, whereas all participants in the TRUS group received antibiotics. However, participants more commonly reported pain and embarrassment immediately after LATP biopsy.

Concerns over infectious complications, including post-biopsy urinary sepsis, have driven the transition from TRUS to LATP. While recent randomized controlled trials comparing these approaches have reported inconclusive findings for cancer detection and infection rates—potentially due to trial designs, inadequate power, and low event rates—LATP showed fewer infections requiring hospital admission in the first 7 days (one [<1%] of 562 versus seven [1%] of 564 for TRUS) and fewer overall infectious complications in the 4-month post-biopsy period (six [1%] of 562 versus 13 [2%] of 564 for TRUS).

In the first 7 days post-biopsy, infection requiring hospital admission occurred in 1 (<1%) of 562 individuals allocated to the LATP group versus 7 (1%) of 564 allocated to the TRUS group (OR 0.14 [95% CI 0.02-1-15]). Within 35 days, these figures increased to 2 (<1%) for LATP participants and 9 (2%) for TRUS participants, respectively.

We recommend performing rectal swab-based TPAs in patients undergoing TRUS-PB due to a clinically relevant reduction in fUTI incidence; however, their overall effect remains unclear despite being studied in randomized controlled trials, likely due to small sample sizes.

While EAU guidelines recommend TPUS-PB as the first choice, for planned TRUS-PB, Targeted Prophylactic Antibiotic Strategy (TPAS) based on rectal swab culture should be considered to increase patient safety by reducing infectious complications. Although the EAU also recommends povidone-iodine rectal preparation prior to TRUS-PB, studies show significant heterogeneity due to inconsistent performance or reporting of this disinfection.
TPAs based on rectal swab culture significantly decreased the rate of fUTI after TRUS-PB, resulting in a 46% and twofold reduction in risk compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics.

From an antimicrobial stewardship perspective, recommended options for antibiotic prophylaxis in transrectal biopsy include targeted prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis using two or more different classes of antibiotics.

For transrectal biopsy, either target prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis involving two or more different classes of antibiotics, is recommended (though this recommendation is weak); transperineal biopsy, however, requires routine surgical disinfection of the perineal skin.
An evidence-based recommendation (grade A), modified in 2025, states that transrectal core biopsy should be performed with antibiotic prophylaxis.
TRPB continues to be widely performed worldwide for various practical reasons.
A transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) is an essential procedure to confirm prostate cancer, with transperineal prostate biopsy also noted.

"TRexit" signifies a shift away from transrectal practices in prostate biopsy, aiming to mitigate infection risks and the emergence of resistant microbial strains while preserving diagnostic precision, despite transrectal biopsy (TRBx) still being asserted as easy, effective, and safe to use.

Based on three RCTs (PREVENT, ProBE-PC, PERFECT), the TR technique, commonly administered with antibiotic prophylaxis to mitigate infection risks or after a rectal swab, showed no difference from TP-Tbx in detecting csPCa (OR 0.9, 95% CI: 0.7-1.1) or ISUP 1 PCa (OR 1.1, 95% CI: 0.8-1.4), with similar postprocedural infection (OR 0.8, 95% CI: 0.4-1.8), sepsis (OR 0.6, 95% CI: 0.1-4.5), and urinary retention rates (OR 0.5, 95% CI: 0.1-1.6).

Preliminary evidence suggests a directionality in key outcomes, including infection and sepsis, that appears to favor TP-Tbx; however, these non-statistically significant findings warrant further investigation to confirm their potential advantages.

Despite lower upfront procedural costs, the TR-Tbx approach may incur significant additional costs and logistical challenges due to the necessity of preprocedure rectal swabs and tailored antibiotic prophylaxis. The TR approach also has a higher chance of infection, up to 5-7% [22] in real-world data, due to rectal mucosa involvement, typically requiring more comprehensive antibiotic protocols.

TRBx inherently carries a potential for infection, particularly sepsis, with numerous studies, including He et al. [10], demonstrating a much higher incidence of infectious complications such as symptomatic UTIs and fever, compared to TPBx. However, key findings reported no significant difference in composite infection rates (2.7% vs. 2.6%, p = 0.89) between the two approaches, and one study [33] found neither method induced sepsis.

The benefits of detecting clinically significant prostate cancer (csPCa) and the safety of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-targeted transperineal (TP) prostate biopsy (TP-Tbx) versus transrectal (TR) approaches are still a matter of debate. A review aims to compare the efficacy and safety of TP-Tbx and MRI-targeted TR biopsy (TR-Tbx).

Urology association guidelines from the two major organizations, the European Association of Urology (EAU) and the American Urological Association (AUA), provide conflicting recommendations on the best prostate biopsy approach. The EAU strongly recommends the Transperineal (TP) approach, citing reduced infectious complications and supporting it as the preferred method for prostate cancer diagnosis, while the AUA offers no clear guidance due to limited randomized controlled trial data, considering both TP and Transrectal (TR) approaches safe and appropriate.

While transperineal (TP) and transrectal (TR) prostate biopsy approaches show no significant differences in prostate cancer detection and complications, the MRI-targeted TP approach may be advantageous as it can be performed safely without antibiotics, potentially reducing antibiotic resistance.

Prostate biopsies are a key step in diagnosing prostate cancer, performed via either transrectal (TR) or transperineal (TP) routes. While both approaches offer similar diagnostic power, the TP approach generally results in fewer infectious complications.

TP-Tbx and TR-Tbx show similar results in detecting PCa, with comparable rates of infection, urinary retention, and effectiveness in managing biopsy-associated pain; however, TP-Tbx can safely omit antibiotics without increasing infection risk, unlike TR-Tbx, which aligns with antibiotic stewardship goals. Despite no clear overall advantage of TP-Tbx in current evidence, preliminary, non-statistically significant findings suggest it may result in lower sepsis rates, with the directionality in key outcomes (infection and sepsis) favoring the TP approach and warranting further investigation, which indicates the tendency to exclude TR-Tbx with prophylactic antibiotics could be moderated.

TP-Tbx could potentially reduce or eliminate the need for prophylactic antibiotics, aligning with antibiotic stewardship goals and reducing reliance on broad-spectrum antibiotics, which are important factors in selecting the optimal biopsy technique. Concurrently, the tendency to exclude TR-Tbx with prophylactic antibiotics due to infection concerns could be moderated.

Transrectal (ultrasound-guided) prostate biopsy (TRPB) was the gold standard for decades, but the European Association of Urology (EAU) now recommends transperineal prostate biopsy (TPPB) due to its comparably lower rates of infectious complications, infection, hospitalization, and sepsis. Despite this, TRPB remains widely performed for practical reasons, and if planned, antibiotic prophylaxis and povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended.
When Transrectal Prostate Biopsy (TRPB) is planned, antibiotic prophylaxis and povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended.

Despite European Association of Urology guidelines recommending the transperineal (TP) approach, the choice between transrectal (TR) and TP techniques for Tbx remains debated. Current evidence shows no clear advantage of TP-Tbx over TR-Tbx, with both methods having similar PCa detection rates and comparable rates of infections, urinary retention, and biopsy-associated pain.

A meta-analysis reaffirmed no clear superiority of the transperineal (TP-Tbx) over the transrectal (TR-Tbx) approach for infection prevention or overall cancer detection, with both demonstrating similar efficacy for clinically significant prostate cancer (csPCa) and diagnostic utility. Although high-quality evidence within the study specifically favored TP for prostate cancer detection, the overall findings suggest that excluding TR from current practices may be moderated, despite international guidelines favoring TP.

A meta-analysis of 11 studies (1,753 patients) demonstrated a significant reduction in infections with antibiotic prophylaxis during transrectal biopsy (RR 0.56, 95% CI 0.40-0.77), recommending targeted prophylaxis via rectal swab for high-risk patients. Conversely, transperineal biopsy allows for the omission of antibiotic prophylaxis if no infection or prostatitis is present, with one systematic review showing no increased infection rate without its use (0.05% vs. 0.08%; p=0.2).

Rectal cleansing appears to be the most effective strategy for preventing infectious complications, potentially comparable to or better than transperineal biopsy; however, many comparisons are indirect and recent trials show no significant difference between transrectal and transperineal approaches. Consequently, there is insufficient evidence to abandon transrectal biopsy, particularly when combined with pre-procedural rectal cleansing or culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis, and further direct RCTs are needed to determine the safest approach.

Given the projected doubling of global prostate cancer incidence by 2040, the transperineal biopsy approach, which current studies suggest does not require pre-procedural antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP), is favored over the transrectal approach, where PAP will always be necessary. This pragmatic and forward-looking perspective is supported by high-confidence studies showing no inferiority in infectious endpoints for PAP-free transperineal biopsy compared to PAP-accompanied transrectal biopsy, despite this being an "apples-to-oranges comparison."

Both transperineal and transrectal prostate biopsies are acceptable approaches, with transrectal biopsies requiring pre-procedural rectal cleansing or culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis (strategies proven and incorporated in guidelines) to address significant infectious complications, especially given millions of procedures yearly. Transperineal biopsies optimize antibiotic stewardship, but the comparative effectiveness of these and other strategies (like avoiding antibiotics for transperineal) remains unknown.

While TRUS-PB remains the gold standard, rectal mucosa cleaning with antiseptic solutions (like chlorhexidine and povidone-iodine) is a validated method that reduces infectious complications. A study suggests that mechanical cleansing with saline is a cost-effective, side-effect-free alternative for infection prevention, particularly beneficial for patients with antiseptic allergies.
Affirmed antibiotic prophylaxis strategies involve targeted prophylaxis based on a rectal swab or stool culture, and augmented prophylaxis with two or more different antibiotic classes.

The TRANSLATE study demonstrated fewer post-biopsy infections, including hospitalizations, following LATP compared to TRUS, with 89% of LATP biopsies safely performed without antibiotics (the 11% receiving antibiotics largely due to protocol deviations), which is important for antibiotic stewardship. However, the study could not include major UK cities already fully transitioned to LATP, did not incorporate regular targeted antibiotic prophylaxis using pre-procedure rectal swabs, and acknowledged that excluding higher-risk participants likely reduced infection rates in both groups.

TRUS biopsy is performed with local anaesthetic infiltration and standard pre- and post-procedure antibiotics, though TRANSLATE recruitment centers in the UK did not routinely use enhanced or rectal culture-guided prophylaxis. Growing concerns about infectious complications following TRUS biopsy are leading to the increased popularity of local anaesthetic transperineal (LATP) biopsy.

The total incidence of acute bacterial prostatitis after TRPB within 30 days was 1.1% (n = 4). The levofloxacin (LVFX)-insusceptible selective media, specifically the CHRO-Magar Orientation with LVFX, demonstrated high accuracy with 98.1% sensitivity and 94.7% specificity when compared to the broth microdilution method.

An updated meta-analysis of nine RCTs with 3,096 patients confirmed that targeted therapy, guided by rectal swab microbiology in cases of fluoroquinolone resistance, is associated with reduced infectious complications [RR 0.52 (0.39 to 0.69)]. Additionally, another meta-analysis of ten RCTs with 2,787 patients found augmented prophylaxis, which combines two or more different classes of antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolone with aminoglycoside or cephalosporin), to be superior to standard prophylaxis.

Biopsies traditionally involve antibiotic prophylaxis to reduce infectious complications, but growing antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and the adoption of antimicrobial stewardship necessitate approaches that reduce antibiotic use. In included trials, antibiotic prophylaxis used fluoroquinolone-based regimens, which are now critically viewed due to high AMR levels, a low threshold for acquiring resistance, and increasing awareness of their side-effect profile among providers and patients.

Ten RCTs comparing TP and TR approaches reported infectious complications after a prostate biopsy, with seven studies showing a 77% lower risk of hospitalization for infectious complications with a TP biopsy than a TR biopsy. Hospitalization reflects increased severity of complications and a higher risk of sepsis, making it the most sensitive surrogate for serious infections not meeting sepsis criteria.

Prostate biopsies can be performed via either a transrectal (TR) or transperineal (TP) route. The TP approach generally causes fewer infectious complications, with current literature suggesting safe omission of periprocedural antibiotic prophylaxis [11], whereas TR biopsies are less resource-intensive and postulated to cause less patient discomfort, but require antibiotic prophylaxis and carry concerns of a higher risk of severe infections.

This multicenter, randomized controlled trial investigated the effectiveness of pre-procedural screening rectal cultures with selective media to identify FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli and guide appropriate prophylactic antibiotics (LVFX or TAZ/PIPC), alongside povidone-iodine rectal disinfection, for preventing acute bacterial prostatitis after transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) in low-infectious-risk patients amidst rising FQ-resistant rates.

Two RCTs (ProBE-PC and PREVENT) investigated the infection rates of TPBx and TRBx [26,32], with key findings from one trial showing no significant difference in composite infection rates (0% vs. 1.4%, p = 0.059) between them [32]. TPBx, however, offers an advantage regarding infectious complications by completely excluding the inherent risk of seeding bacteria into the rectum, as it does not pass through the rectal mucosa.

Transperineal biopsy (TPBx) is increasingly favored and strongly recommended by the European Association of Urology due to its diagnostic advantages, safety, and lower risk of infectious complications, a shift from transrectal biopsy (TRBx), which became standard in the 1980s. This deviation, termed "TRexit," aims to mitigate infection and resistant microbial strain risks while preserving diagnostic precision, with global adoption rising from 14% to 25% in the UK (2014-2017) and from 26% to 57% in Australia/New Zealand (2015-2019).

TRUS-PB remains the most commonly used and gold standard method for the diagnosis of prostate cancer, despite being a diagnostic method with high morbidity where complications can range from asymptomatic urinary tract infections (UTI) to sepsis and even death. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Transrectal ultrasound prostate biopsy (TRUS-PB) is associated with worrying complications including infection, hospitalization, and sepsis, which can make patients reluctant to undergo repeat biopsies and results in significantly higher hospitalization rates. In contrast, the transperineal method has a lower incidence of infection, with no hospitalizations observed in one study of 245 patients. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Despite EAU guidelines recommending transperineal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy (TPUS-PB) for its lower infection rate, transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy (TRUS-PB) remains widely used and plays an important role in real-world practice, mainly due to TPUS-PB's complex technical demands and higher patient discomfort, while TRUS is also the least costly option. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy (TRUS-PB) remains widely used for diagnosing prostate cancer due to its lower cost, simplicity, and widespread availability, and because the guideline-recommended transperineal approach (TPUS-PB) has greater patient discomfort and complex technical demands, despite TPUS-PB allowing antibiotic prophylaxis omission. While TRUS-PB is associated with significant infectious complications, these can be halved by using culture-guided antibiotics. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transperineal Biopsy: Limited Need for Antibiotic Prophylaxis
nuggets: TRANSLATE recruitment centers in this UK study did not use enhanced or rectal culture-guided prophylaxis, including targeted antibiotic prophylaxis with pre-procedure rectal swabs, as these are not routinely practiced in the UK but might be in other countries. The study recognized that excluding participants at higher infection risk, necessary for successful randomisation, likely reduced the infection event rate in both groups, with the infection rate for the modified intention-to-treat population available in Table 4. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The PREVENT trial found no infections in 372 transperineal (TP) cases, versus six (1.6%) febrile but nonsevere infections in 370 transrectal (TR) cases, showing a -1% difference (95% CI: -3.5% to 0.3%, p=0.01). Notably, TP biopsies without preventative antibiotics and TR biopsies with targeted antibiotic prophylaxis both showed no significant infectious complications, although the ProBE-PC study reported that all TR procedures used 1-day antibiotic prophylaxis without rectal cultures, unlike TP. (Confidence: 80.0%)

A systematic review, including a subgroup analysis of ten studies and randomized data such as the NORAPP trial, found no statistically significant difference in overall infectious complications, hospitalizations, or febrile infectious outcomes (p=0.47) when comparing transperineal (TP) biopsies performed with and without antibiotic prophylaxis. Therefore, for patients without risk factors, it may be considered safe to forgo antibiotic prophylaxis in TP biopsies, a conclusion consistent with and extending existing evidence. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Antibiotic prophylaxis has limited additional value in transperineal (TP) biopsies, aligning with antimicrobial stewardship principles; in contrast, other procedures are less resource intensive but require antibiotic prophylaxis and raise concerns of a higher risk of severe infections. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Urology Guidelines Drive Transperineal Biopsy for Antibiotic Stewardship
nuggets: The transrectal approach is noted to contravene antibiotic stewardship principles, a central focus of the 2024 European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines on urological infections. These guidelines provide evidence-based recommendations for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention, emphasizing antimicrobial stewardship to minimize antibiotic use and combat the escalating global threat of antimicrobial resistance through specific guidance on antibiotic selection, dosing, and duration, while acknowledging weak evidence for prophylaxis in some procedures like prostatectomy. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Both biopsy approaches demonstrate low overall toxicity, are generally safe for clinical use in the populations studied, and the transperineal (TP) approach does not carry an increasing risk of urinary retention. While there is a clear trend across studies to minimize antibiotic use to reduce antibiotic resistance, recent European Association of Urology guidelines specifically direct urologists towards the TP approach. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines maintain a neutral position on both transrectal and transperineal approaches due to a lack of comparative RCTs on infection rates, also stating that the value of prophylactic antibiotics in TPBx is unknown and its wider implementation requires adequate training and resources. Meanwhile, the European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines describe growing evidence suggesting antibiotic prophylaxis may not be required for TPBx, but the panel awaits ongoing RCT findings, mindful that unnecessary prophylactic antibiotic administration can lead to antibiotic resistance across the medical system. (Confidence: 100.0%)

The exclusive adoption of transperineal (TP) biopsies reduces antibiotic usage by decreasing infectious complications and safely omitting periprocedural antibiotic prophylaxis. This is a crucial point for the urological community's debate on optimal biopsy approaches, given the significant implications of antibiotic overuse and associated antimicrobial resistance (AMR) for individual patients, the general population, and their microbiome. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Rectal Cleansing Reduces Transrectal Biopsy Infectious Complications
nuggets: An updated meta-analysis of eleven RCTs including 2,237 men showed that use of a rectal povidone-iodine preparation before transrectal biopsy, in addition to antimicrobial prophylaxis, resulted in a significantly lower rate of infectious complications [RR (95% CIs) 0.47 (0.36 to 0.61)]. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Mechanical cleaning methods with saline are cheap, easy to apply, and have no side effects, protecting against possible infections like other antiseptic solutions with similar results for general complications, fever, acute prostatitis, and sepsis, and serving as an alternative for patients with antiseptic allergies. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Given increasing infection rates and antibiotic resistance, particularly to commonly used quinolones, rectal cleansing with povidone-iodine combined with antibiotic prophylaxis during transrectal biopsy has been shown to reduce infectious complications. Current urology guidelines recommend this approach when local infectious complication rates are high. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Transrectal cleansing with Povidone-iodine is an additional measure to reduce infection during transrectal biopsy. This approach, supported by a meta-analysis of 11 studies (2,237 patients) showing a relative risk of 0.47 (95% CI 0.36-0.61), is a new consensus-based recommendation for 2025. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transperineal Biopsy: Lower Infection Risk, Guiding Practice
nuggets: The EAU strongly recommends the Transperineal (TP) approach due to its reduced incidence of infectious complications, while the AUA, citing limited RCT data, offers unclear guidance but considers both TP and Transrectal (TR) approaches safe and appropriate diagnostic procedures. Although both approaches provide similar diagnostic power, infectious complications appear to favor TP, thus future research must be adequately powered and follow standardized definitions for infectious outcomes. (Confidence: 80.0%)

High-level evidence confirms that the transperineal (TP) biopsy route significantly reduces the risk of infectious complications requiring hospitalisation compared to the transrectal route. Hospitalisation serves as the most sensitive surrogate for serious infections (not meeting sepsis criteria), reflecting increased severity of complications and a higher risk of sepsis; furthermore, antibiotic prophylaxis offers no additional benefit in a TP biopsy, reinforcing antimicrobial stewardship principles. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Clear international guidance on biopsy routes and infection risk, grounded in robust evidence, is needed to support consistent and safe clinical practice across regions. These results may help inform decisions about biopsy technique and infection prevention strategies. (Confidence: 80.0%)

There was a significant association between biopsy approaches and fever, with fever occurring more frequently after TR biopsies, while the TP route showed less frequent postinterventional fever (OR 0.68, 95% CI 0.52-0.89). Furthermore, the TP route significantly reduced the risk of hospitalization for infectious complications by 77% compared to the TR route (OR 0.23, 95% CI 0.10-0.54), with no statistically significant difference in infectious complications for TP biopsies whether antibiotics were used or not, unlike TR biopsies which universally utilized antibiotic prophylaxis. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Povidone-iodine Rectal Cleansing for Transrectal Biopsy Infection Reduction
nuggets: Use rectal cleansing with povidone-iodine in men prior to transrectal prostate biopsy. (Confidence: 80.0%)

For transrectal prostate biopsy, moderate evidence from numerous low-to-moderate quality studies and four meta-analyses suggests that targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP) guided by pre-procedural rectal swab results, coupled with Povidone-iodine rectal disinfection to minimize bacterial load, is suitable for reducing postoperative infectious complications. While one meta-analysis (Jazayeri et al. 2020) reported a lower but non-significant infection rate with targeted PAP, its authors still concluded its suitability; conversely, two recent RCTs (Jacewicz 2022; Chernyscheva 2021) found no higher rates of infection, fever, or sepsis when PAP was omitted. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Rectal povidone-iodine cleansing before transrectal prostate biopsy, combined with antimicrobial prophylaxis, is strongly recommended due to a meta-analysis of eleven RCTs (2,237 men) showing it significantly lowers infectious complications (RR: 0.47; 95% CI [0.36–0.61]); conversely, the transperineal approach is strongly recommended for prostate biopsy given its low infectious risk and improved antibiotic stewardship. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Rectal cleansing prior to transrectal prostate biopsy appears to be the most effective strategy for reducing infectious complications, including sepsis, potentially outperforming transperineal biopsy and rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis. However, despite current guidelines recommending transperineal biopsy, its effectiveness compared to rectal cleansing and culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis remains unclear, necessitating further randomized controlled trials. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transperineal Prostate Biopsy: Lower Infection, Less Antibiotics
nuggets: The transperineal approach is recommended for prostate biopsy due to its lower risk of infectious complications and better antibiotic stewardship. While emerging evidence suggests antibiotic prophylaxis may not be required for transperineal biopsy, a panel is awaiting further RCT findings for a formal recommendation, given that all prostate biopsy recommendations require level 1a evidence. (Confidence: 80.0%)

While guidelines now recommend transperineal (TPB) over transrectal (TRB) prostate biopsy, and empirical antibiotics alone are not recommended for TRB, there is insufficient evidence to abandon TRB when combined with rectal cleansing and culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis. These modifications significantly reduce infectious complications, potentially comparable to or even better than TPB, but direct comparisons are scarce, necessitating further RCTs to determine the safest approach. (Confidence: 100.0%)

A systematic review and meta-analysis comparing transrectal (TR) and transperineal (TP) prostate biopsy techniques, which offer similar diagnostic power, found that the TP route significantly reduces the risk of hospitalization due to infectious complications. This evidence reinforces antimicrobial stewardship principles by highlighting the lack of additional benefit from antibiotic prophylaxis in TP biopsies, addressing previous urological guideline inconsistencies and supporting the European Association of Urology's recommendation of TP as the preferred approach for prostate cancer diagnosis. (Confidence: 80.0%)

An updated meta-analysis of ten RCTs (4188 prostate biopsies) found the transperineal (TP) approach to be associated with lower rates of infectious complications, including hospitalisation (77% reduced risk; odds ratio 0.23, 95% CI 0.10-0.54) and fever (odds ratio 0.68, 95% CI 0.52-0.89), compared to the transrectal (TR) route. Notably, all TR biopsies utilized antibiotic prophylaxis, whereas TP biopsies showed no significant difference in infectious complications with or without antibiotics. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Selective Media Screening for Post-TRPB Prostatitis Prevention
nuggets: Our trial, which focused on patients with low infectious risk (373 finished out of 403 enrolled before early termination on April 8, 2024), implicated that screening with selective media before TRPB may provide additive value to preventing post-biopsy prostatitis. Piperacillin/tazobactam can be recommended when FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli is detected, while further evaluation of selective media screening is needed for patients with underlying conditions negatively impacting immune function. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Piperacillin/tazobactam (TAZ/PIPC) can be recommended or considered when FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli is detected. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Selective media, including 2 kinds of CHROMagar media, utilize dissolved antimicrobials to rapidly and effectively detect targeted strains such as FQ-resistant and ESBL-producing E. coli, thereby improving screening accuracy. These media can be prepared for specific antimicrobials to guide appropriate targeted prophylaxis, providing additive beneficial value for patients undergoing TRPB by addressing worldwide trends in antimicrobial resistance. (Confidence: 100.0%)

In the control group (CG), the positive-culture group administered TAZ/PIPC developed no acute bacterial prostatitis, and the incidence of post-biopsy prostatitis (0/67 cases) was not significantly different from the 3/120 cases observed in the negative-culture group administered LVFX (P = .19). (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Prostate Biopsy: Infection Risk, Prophylaxis, and Methods
nuggets: While transrectal prostate biopsy, even with preoperative rectal screening for multi-drug resistant organisms and targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (t-PAP) reducing broad-spectrum antibiotic use by over 80% (favorable for antibiotic stewardship), still carries inherently higher infection rates (5-7%) and a sepsis risk (0.3-9.4%), the transperineal approach offers a superior alternative. Transperineal biopsy, with comparable tumor detection and a significantly lower infection rate (0% even without prophylaxis versus 1.4% for transrectal with PAP), can often entirely forgo antibiotic prophylaxis, thereby aligning more strongly with antibiotic stewardship principles, provided thorough perineal disinfection and urinary tract infection exclusion are performed. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Antimicrobial prophylaxis is recommended for transrectal prostate biopsy, involving targeted prophylaxis based on rectal or stool culture, augmented prophylaxis with two or more antibiotic classes, or alternative antibiotics such as cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefixime) and aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin, amikacin). However, while fosfomycin trometamol (e.g., 3g before and 3g 24-48h after biopsy) is listed as an alternative, its indication for prostate biopsy has been withdrawn in Germany due to manufacturers' failure to submit necessary pharmacokinetic data, requiring urologists to check local guidance regarding its use. (Confidence: 100.0%)

While direct comparisons are scarce, current findings suggest insufficient evidence to recommend abandoning transrectal prostate biopsy, making it a prudent option for urologists and further trials alongside transperineal biopsy. For transrectal biopsy, pre-procedural rectal cleansing or rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis significantly reduce infectious complications, potentially equalling or surpassing transperineal outcomes, and are recommended over empirical antibiotics alone. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TRPB Prophylaxis: FQ Alternatives and Antimicrobial Stewardship
nuggets: Antibiotic prophylaxis before TRPB is mandatory to avoid infectious complications, but the previous gold standard FQs are no longer accepted in the EU for this indication. In a study, there was no significant difference in infectious complications between single-dose and prolonged FMT prophylaxis for TRPBs, and previous antibiotic treatment showed no negative effect on FMT efficacy; therefore, single-dose FMT is recommended to prevent overuse and negative ecological impact. (Confidence: 80.0%)

During targeted prophylaxis, a non-FQ/nonquinolone alternative antibiotic (e.g., FMT) is still needed; augmented prophylaxis, a second suggestion, might have a potential negative ecological impact and is contrary to antibiotic stewardship principles. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Antibiotic prophylaxis before TRPB is mandatory to avoid infectious complications, but the previous gold standard FQs are no longer accepted in the EU for this indication. The current EAU guidelines recommend an algorithm for prophylaxis, outlining options such as targeted prophylaxis (based on rectal swab results, requiring a nonquinolone alternative, and not always feasible), augmented prophylaxis (with potential negative ecological impact and contrary to antibiotic stewardship), and the use of non-FQ alternative antibiotics like FMT. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Targeted Antibiotics Reduce Prostate Biopsy Infections
nuggets: A systematic review and meta-analysis of RCTs found that targeted prophylactic antibiotics (TPAs) based on rectal swab culture, when used prior to TRUS-PB for PCa diagnosis, significantly reduce the incidence of febrile UTI (fUTI) by twofold compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics; however, there was insufficient evidence to show a significant difference regarding the risk of sepsis. (Confidence: 100.0%)

The study aimed to assess the efficacy of targeted prophylactic antibiotics (TPAs), based on rectal swabs, in reducing infectious complications after TRUS-PB compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics. This follows a previous meta-analysis [6] which showed that combining prophylactic antibiotics with povidone-iodine rectal preparation before TRUS-PB significantly reduces the incidence of febrile urinary tract infection (fUTI) compared to empiric prophylactic antibiotic monotherapy (RR: 0.47, 95% CI: 0.3-0.75, p = 0.001). (Confidence: 100.0%)

Two RCTs, ProBE-PC (monocentric, 753 patients, 30-day composite infection rate) and PREVENT (multicenter, 658 patients, 7-day post-biopsy infection rates), found no significant difference in composite infection rates between transperineal (TPBx) and transrectal (TRBx) biopsies (2.7% vs. 2.6%, p=0.89 for ProBE-PC; 0% vs. 1.4%, p=0.059 for PREVENT). While TRBx involved targeted antibiotics based on rectal cultures, TPBx typically either prescribed antibiotics without cultures (employing augmented oral therapy or intramuscular ceftriaxone) or omitted prophylaxis in most cases (98.9%), and neither approach induced sepsis in the ProBE-PC trial. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: LATP vs TRUS Biopsy: Infection Rates and Outcomes
nuggets: LATP biopsy, performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation, typically did not involve antibiotics for most participants (503 [89%] of 567) according to protocol, whereas all participants in the TRUS group received antibiotics. However, participants more commonly reported pain and embarrassment immediately after LATP biopsy. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Concerns over infectious complications, including post-biopsy urinary sepsis, have driven the transition from TRUS to LATP. While recent randomized controlled trials comparing these approaches have reported inconclusive findings for cancer detection and infection rates—potentially due to trial designs, inadequate power, and low event rates—LATP showed fewer infections requiring hospital admission in the first 7 days (one [<1%] of 562 versus seven [1%] of 564 for TRUS) and fewer overall infectious complications in the 4-month post-biopsy period (six [1%] of 562 versus 13 [2%] of 564 for TRUS). (Confidence: 80.0%)

In the first 7 days post-biopsy, infection requiring hospital admission occurred in 1 (<1%) of 562 individuals allocated to the LATP group versus 7 (1%) of 564 allocated to the TRUS group (OR 0.14 [95% CI 0.02-1-15]). Within 35 days, these figures increased to 2 (<1%) for LATP participants and 9 (2%) for TRUS participants, respectively. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Rectal Swab TPAS Reduces TRUS-PB Infection Risk
nuggets: We recommend performing rectal swab-based TPAs in patients undergoing TRUS-PB due to a clinically relevant reduction in fUTI incidence; however, their overall effect remains unclear despite being studied in randomized controlled trials, likely due to small sample sizes. (Confidence: 100.0%)

While EAU guidelines recommend TPUS-PB as the first choice, for planned TRUS-PB, Targeted Prophylactic Antibiotic Strategy (TPAS) based on rectal swab culture should be considered to increase patient safety by reducing infectious complications. Although the EAU also recommends povidone-iodine rectal preparation prior to TRUS-PB, studies show significant heterogeneity due to inconsistent performance or reporting of this disinfection. (Confidence: 100.0%)

TPAs based on rectal swab culture significantly decreased the rate of fUTI after TRUS-PB, resulting in a 46% and twofold reduction in risk compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transrectal Biopsy Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Strategies and Updates
nuggets: From an antimicrobial stewardship perspective, recommended options for antibiotic prophylaxis in transrectal biopsy include targeted prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis using two or more different classes of antibiotics. (Confidence: 80.0%)

For transrectal biopsy, either target prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis involving two or more different classes of antibiotics, is recommended (though this recommendation is weak); transperineal biopsy, however, requires routine surgical disinfection of the perineal skin. (Confidence: 80.0%)
An evidence-based recommendation (grade A), modified in 2025, states that transrectal core biopsy should be performed with antibiotic prophylaxis. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transrectal Prostate Biopsy: Usage, 'TRexit', and Infection Risks
nuggets: TRPB continues to be widely performed worldwide for various practical reasons. (Confidence: 80.0%)
A transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) is an essential procedure to confirm prostate cancer, with transperineal prostate biopsy also noted. (Confidence: 100.0%)

"TRexit" signifies a shift away from transrectal practices in prostate biopsy, aiming to mitigate infection risks and the emergence of resistant microbial strains while preserving diagnostic precision, despite transrectal biopsy (TRBx) still being asserted as easy, effective, and safe to use. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TR vs TP-Tbx Biopsy: PCa Detection and Safety
nuggets: Based on three RCTs (PREVENT, ProBE-PC, PERFECT), the TR technique, commonly administered with antibiotic prophylaxis to mitigate infection risks or after a rectal swab, showed no difference from TP-Tbx in detecting csPCa (OR 0.9, 95% CI: 0.7-1.1) or ISUP 1 PCa (OR 1.1, 95% CI: 0.8-1.4), with similar postprocedural infection (OR 0.8, 95% CI: 0.4-1.8), sepsis (OR 0.6, 95% CI: 0.1-4.5), and urinary retention rates (OR 0.5, 95% CI: 0.1-1.6). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Preliminary evidence suggests a directionality in key outcomes, including infection and sepsis, that appears to favor TP-Tbx; however, these non-statistically significant findings warrant further investigation to confirm their potential advantages. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transrectal Biopsy: Infection Risks, Complications, and Costs
nuggets: Despite lower upfront procedural costs, the TR-Tbx approach may incur significant additional costs and logistical challenges due to the necessity of preprocedure rectal swabs and tailored antibiotic prophylaxis. The TR approach also has a higher chance of infection, up to 5-7% [22] in real-world data, due to rectal mucosa involvement, typically requiring more comprehensive antibiotic protocols. (Confidence: 80.0%)

TRBx inherently carries a potential for infection, particularly sepsis, with numerous studies, including He et al. [10], demonstrating a much higher incidence of infectious complications such as symptomatic UTIs and fever, compared to TPBx. However, key findings reported no significant difference in composite infection rates (2.7% vs. 2.6%, p = 0.89) between the two approaches, and one study [33] found neither method induced sepsis. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Prostate Biopsy: TP vs TR, Conflicting Guidelines
nuggets: The benefits of detecting clinically significant prostate cancer (csPCa) and the safety of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-targeted transperineal (TP) prostate biopsy (TP-Tbx) versus transrectal (TR) approaches are still a matter of debate. A review aims to compare the efficacy and safety of TP-Tbx and MRI-targeted TR biopsy (TR-Tbx). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Urology association guidelines from the two major organizations, the European Association of Urology (EAU) and the American Urological Association (AUA), provide conflicting recommendations on the best prostate biopsy approach. The EAU strongly recommends the Transperineal (TP) approach, citing reduced infectious complications and supporting it as the preferred method for prostate cancer diagnosis, while the AUA offers no clear guidance due to limited randomized controlled trial data, considering both TP and Transrectal (TR) approaches safe and appropriate. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transperineal Biopsy: Fewer Infections, Less Antibiotic Resistance
nuggets: While transperineal (TP) and transrectal (TR) prostate biopsy approaches show no significant differences in prostate cancer detection and complications, the MRI-targeted TP approach may be advantageous as it can be performed safely without antibiotics, potentially reducing antibiotic resistance. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Prostate biopsies are a key step in diagnosing prostate cancer, performed via either transrectal (TR) or transperineal (TP) routes. While both approaches offer similar diagnostic power, the TP approach generally results in fewer infectious complications. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TP-Tbx: Advancing Antibiotic Stewardship in Biopsy
nuggets: TP-Tbx and TR-Tbx show similar results in detecting PCa, with comparable rates of infection, urinary retention, and effectiveness in managing biopsy-associated pain; however, TP-Tbx can safely omit antibiotics without increasing infection risk, unlike TR-Tbx, which aligns with antibiotic stewardship goals. Despite no clear overall advantage of TP-Tbx in current evidence, preliminary, non-statistically significant findings suggest it may result in lower sepsis rates, with the directionality in key outcomes (infection and sepsis) favoring the TP approach and warranting further investigation, which indicates the tendency to exclude TR-Tbx with prophylactic antibiotics could be moderated. (Confidence: 80.0%)

TP-Tbx could potentially reduce or eliminate the need for prophylactic antibiotics, aligning with antibiotic stewardship goals and reducing reliance on broad-spectrum antibiotics, which are important factors in selecting the optimal biopsy technique. Concurrently, the tendency to exclude TR-Tbx with prophylactic antibiotics due to infection concerns could be moderated. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transrectal Biopsy: Infection Risk and Prophylaxis
nuggets: Transrectal (ultrasound-guided) prostate biopsy (TRPB) was the gold standard for decades, but the European Association of Urology (EAU) now recommends transperineal prostate biopsy (TPPB) due to its comparably lower rates of infectious complications, infection, hospitalization, and sepsis. Despite this, TRPB remains widely performed for practical reasons, and if planned, antibiotic prophylaxis and povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended. (Confidence: 80.0%)
When Transrectal Prostate Biopsy (TRPB) is planned, antibiotic prophylaxis and povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Prostate Biopsy Techniques: Similar Efficacy Despite Guidelines.
nuggets: Despite European Association of Urology guidelines recommending the transperineal (TP) approach, the choice between transrectal (TR) and TP techniques for Tbx remains debated. Current evidence shows no clear advantage of TP-Tbx over TR-Tbx, with both methods having similar PCa detection rates and comparable rates of infections, urinary retention, and biopsy-associated pain. (Confidence: 80.0%)

A meta-analysis reaffirmed no clear superiority of the transperineal (TP-Tbx) over the transrectal (TR-Tbx) approach for infection prevention or overall cancer detection, with both demonstrating similar efficacy for clinically significant prostate cancer (csPCa) and diagnostic utility. Although high-quality evidence within the study specifically favored TP for prostate cancer detection, the overall findings suggest that excluding TR from current practices may be moderated, despite international guidelines favoring TP. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Prostate Biopsy Infection Prevention Strategies
nuggets: A meta-analysis of 11 studies (1,753 patients) demonstrated a significant reduction in infections with antibiotic prophylaxis during transrectal biopsy (RR 0.56, 95% CI 0.40-0.77), recommending targeted prophylaxis via rectal swab for high-risk patients. Conversely, transperineal biopsy allows for the omission of antibiotic prophylaxis if no infection or prostatitis is present, with one systematic review showing no increased infection rate without its use (0.05% vs. 0.08%; p=0.2). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Rectal cleansing appears to be the most effective strategy for preventing infectious complications, potentially comparable to or better than transperineal biopsy; however, many comparisons are indirect and recent trials show no significant difference between transrectal and transperineal approaches. Consequently, there is insufficient evidence to abandon transrectal biopsy, particularly when combined with pre-procedural rectal cleansing or culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis, and further direct RCTs are needed to determine the safest approach. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Prostate Biopsy: Antibiotic Prophylaxis and Infection Prevention
nuggets: Given the projected doubling of global prostate cancer incidence by 2040, the transperineal biopsy approach, which current studies suggest does not require pre-procedural antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP), is favored over the transrectal approach, where PAP will always be necessary. This pragmatic and forward-looking perspective is supported by high-confidence studies showing no inferiority in infectious endpoints for PAP-free transperineal biopsy compared to PAP-accompanied transrectal biopsy, despite this being an "apples-to-oranges comparison." (Confidence: 100.0%)

Both transperineal and transrectal prostate biopsies are acceptable approaches, with transrectal biopsies requiring pre-procedural rectal cleansing or culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis (strategies proven and incorporated in guidelines) to address significant infectious complications, especially given millions of procedures yearly. Transperineal biopsies optimize antibiotic stewardship, but the comparative effectiveness of these and other strategies (like avoiding antibiotics for transperineal) remains unknown. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Infection Prevention: Cleansing and Antibiotic Strategies
nuggets: While TRUS-PB remains the gold standard, rectal mucosa cleaning with antiseptic solutions (like chlorhexidine and povidone-iodine) is a validated method that reduces infectious complications. A study suggests that mechanical cleansing with saline is a cost-effective, side-effect-free alternative for infection prevention, particularly beneficial for patients with antiseptic allergies. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Affirmed antibiotic prophylaxis strategies involve targeted prophylaxis based on a rectal swab or stool culture, and augmented prophylaxis with two or more different antibiotic classes. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: LATP Biopsy: Reduced Infections and Antibiotic Use
nuggets: The TRANSLATE study demonstrated fewer post-biopsy infections, including hospitalizations, following LATP compared to TRUS, with 89% of LATP biopsies safely performed without antibiotics (the 11% receiving antibiotics largely due to protocol deviations), which is important for antibiotic stewardship. However, the study could not include major UK cities already fully transitioned to LATP, did not incorporate regular targeted antibiotic prophylaxis using pre-procedure rectal swabs, and acknowledged that excluding higher-risk participants likely reduced infection rates in both groups. (Confidence: 80.0%)

TRUS biopsy is performed with local anaesthetic infiltration and standard pre- and post-procedure antibiotics, though TRANSLATE recruitment centers in the UK did not routinely use enhanced or rectal culture-guided prophylaxis. Growing concerns about infectious complications following TRUS biopsy are leading to the increased popularity of local anaesthetic transperineal (LATP) biopsy. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Acute Prostatitis Incidence and Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing
nuggets: The total incidence of acute bacterial prostatitis after TRPB within 30 days was 1.1% (n = 4). In this study, the incidences were 1.6% (n = 3, all negative-culture cases) in the CG and 0.5% (n = 1) in the NCG, with no significant difference (P = .3); notably, no prostatitis occurred in the positive-culture group. (Confidence: 100.0%)

The levofloxacin (LVFX)-insusceptible selective media, specifically the CHRO-Magar Orientation with LVFX, demonstrated high accuracy with 98.1% sensitivity and 94.7% specificity when compared to the broth microdilution method. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Optimizing Biopsy Antibiotic Prophylaxis Against Resistance
nuggets: An updated meta-analysis of nine RCTs with 3,096 patients confirmed that targeted therapy, guided by rectal swab microbiology in cases of fluoroquinolone resistance, is associated with reduced infectious complications [RR 0.52 (0.39 to 0.69)]. Additionally, another meta-analysis of ten RCTs with 2,787 patients found augmented prophylaxis, which combines two or more different classes of antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolone with aminoglycoside or cephalosporin), to be superior to standard prophylaxis. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Biopsies traditionally involve antibiotic prophylaxis to reduce infectious complications, but growing antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and the adoption of antimicrobial stewardship necessitate approaches that reduce antibiotic use. In included trials, antibiotic prophylaxis used fluoroquinolone-based regimens, which are now critically viewed due to high AMR levels, a low threshold for acquiring resistance, and increasing awareness of their side-effect profile among providers and patients. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TP vs. TR Prostate Biopsy: Infectious Complications
nuggets: Ten RCTs comparing TP and TR approaches reported infectious complications after a prostate biopsy, with seven studies showing a 77% lower risk of hospitalization for infectious complications with a TP biopsy than a TR biopsy. Hospitalization reflects increased severity of complications and a higher risk of sepsis, making it the most sensitive surrogate for serious infections not meeting sepsis criteria. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Prostate biopsies can be performed via either a transrectal (TR) or transperineal (TP) route. The TP approach generally causes fewer infectious complications, with current literature suggesting safe omission of periprocedural antibiotic prophylaxis [11], whereas TR biopsies are less resource-intensive and postulated to cause less patient discomfort, but require antibiotic prophylaxis and carry concerns of a higher risk of severe infections. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Targeted Prophylaxis for Post-Biopsy Prostatitis Amidst Resistance
nuggets: This multicenter, randomized controlled trial investigated the effectiveness of pre-procedural screening rectal cultures with selective media to identify FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli and guide appropriate prophylactic antibiotics (LVFX or TAZ/PIPC), alongside povidone-iodine rectal disinfection, for preventing acute bacterial prostatitis after transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) in low-infectious-risk patients amidst rising FQ-resistant rates. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TPBx vs. TRBx: Infection & Rectal Seeding Advantage
nuggets: Two RCTs (ProBE-PC and PREVENT) investigated the infection rates of TPBx and TRBx [26,32], with key findings from one trial showing no significant difference in composite infection rates (0% vs. 1.4%, p = 0.059) between them [32]. TPBx, however, offers an advantage regarding infectious complications by completely excluding the inherent risk of seeding bacteria into the rectum, as it does not pass through the rectal mucosa. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TRexit: The Shift to Safer Transperineal Prostate Biopsy
nuggets: Transperineal biopsy (TPBx) is increasingly favored and strongly recommended by the European Association of Urology due to its diagnostic advantages, safety, and lower risk of infectious complications, a shift from transrectal biopsy (TRBx), which became standard in the 1980s. This deviation, termed "TRexit," aims to mitigate infection and resistant microbial strain risks while preserving diagnostic precision, with global adoption rising from 14% to 25% in the UK (2014-2017) and from 26% to 57% in Australia/New Zealand (2015-2019). (Confidence: 100.0%)
